posts.caption: The perfect summer evening activity in Steamboat Springs, Colorado üèîÔ∏èüå≤üõÅüçìWhat to know about this dreamy spot BEFORE you visit Strawberry Park Natural Hot Springs. Make a reservation online in advance, and pay in cash ($20 per person) when you arrive.  Prepare to not have cell service while you‚Äôre there. Bring your own towel and water! Alcohol, glass, and food not allowed by the pools. ‚Ä¢I‚Äôd recommend bringing sandals you can wear in the water.  In the winter, you‚Äôll likely need shoes with good traction to get down the steps to the pools, and know that AWD/snow tires or chains are needed on the icy roads. There are also shuttles you can book instead.  There are changing rooms, but we preferred to show up already in our swimsuits!  There are bathrooms! üöΩ  It‚Äôs clothing optional after dark (~9pm right now), so minors and electronics aren‚Äôt allowed after the sun sets! It‚Äôs very relaxed and not well lit. #coloradoadventures #hotspringscolorado #coloradomountains

posts.caption: üçÉPrinceton‚Äôs Best Kept Secret - Tusculum  Save this for later and make sure to follow me for all things Princeton NJ and real estate  üåø Hidden History + Nature Hike Just outside downtown Princeton lies Tusculum, the 1773 home of John Witherspoon‚Äîsigner of the Declaration of Independence. üá∫üá∏ Though the estate itself is private, the surrounding woods are yours to explore. üó∫Ô∏è Where to wander:‚Ä®‚ú® Mountain Lakes Preserve‚Ä®‚ú® John Witherspoon Woods‚Ä®‚ú® Community Park North‚Ä®‚ú® Pettoranello Gardens Look out for Devil‚Äôs Cave, scenic boardwalks, and peaceful meadows just steps from history. üçÇ and share some of your favorite snapshots! üìç Access trails from: * Mountain Avenue Parking Lot: Provides access to the paved path and the purple trail in Community Park North  * Unitarian Universalist Church Parking Lot: Offers access to the yellow trail leading into Community Park North * Route 206 Parking Lot: Provides access to the sewer line trail, a wide, grassy path that separates Community Park North into pine woods and Pettoranello Gardens These access points are well-connected by foot and cycle paths, making it convenient to explore the interconnected trail system.See you on the trails! ü•æüèïÔ∏èAlana Lutkowski- your go to Greater Princeton NJ real estate agent- making sure you love where you live ‚ù§Ô∏è#PrincetonNJ #Tusculum #NatureWalks #MountainLakesPreserve #princeton #HikingNewJersey #HiddenHistory

posts.caption:
7 Family-Friendly Hikes You Need to Explore! üå≥

Here‚Äôs a fun list of beautiful, family-friendly hikes in NJ & NY! Perfect for beginners, kids, and anyone looking for scenic nature views.

1.Mt Tammany, NJ - Delaware Water Gap üåÑ
A popular and moderately challenging hike with breathtaking views of the Delaware River. The Red Dot Trail (1.5 miles) is a bit steep but rewards you with stunning panoramic views at the summit. Ideal for families with older kids who enjoy an adventurous climb!

2.Taughannock Falls State Park, NY üåä
Easy trails leading to a stunning 215-foot waterfall‚Äîone of the tallest east of the Rockies! The Gorge Trail is flat and great for all ages.

3.Flume Falls, Wilmington, NY üåä
Short and accessible hike with lovely river views. A peaceful spot to explore nature without a strenuous trek.

4.Appalachian Trail Boardwalk, NJ üåº
A flat, easy walk along wooden planks with scenic marsh views. Perfect for little ones or anyone looking for a relaxing stroll.

5.Split Rock Falls, Elizabethtown, NY üí¶
A roadside waterfall with picturesque views and natural pools. Beautiful for a quick stop or picnic with the family.

6.Minnewaska State Park, NY üå≥
Known for gorgeous lake views, waterfalls, and family-friendly paths. The Awosting Falls Trail is an easy, must-do hike.

7.High Falls Gorge, Wilmington, NY üåä
A perfect, easy hike through well-maintained trails and bridges that guide you along roaring waterfalls and unique rock formations. Great for kids!

Which hike are you trying next? Let me know! üåü #Familyfriendlyhiking #hiking with kids

posts.caption:
Behind this small unassuming East Village storefront with colorful stickers on the window lies NYC‚Äôs best mochi store with an even better story. 

The mochis come in light pink boxes and an iridescent tote every customer gets for free. It‚Äôs instagrammable and influencer ready - but to reduce it to just that would not be doing them justice. 

My first impressions are good. The interior is small but cute; the open kitchen clearly shows the effort and care that goes into the desserts. I admit I‚Äôm surprised- the two chefs inside are Ukrainian - contrary to the majority of Asian based places I‚Äôve been to NYC. 

The menu is equally interesting; I see an unexpected amalgamation of flavors and mediums - lime, mint, tonic, and espresso; bubble gum and raspberry mousse in mochi; coconut and mango in milkshake boba. 
I ask for recommendations and one of the chefs helps me order. I soon find out that he is Pavlo, the owner and namesake of Pavlo‚Äôs mochi. My order consists of Mango passion fruit vanilla, Pistachio raspberry, Matcha raspberry, and Strawberry caramel. 

The mochis are packed with care with garnishes of cut fruit on top. It‚Äôs clear that they are carefully crafted. I already know my favorite flavor will be the Mango Passionfruit Vanilla, so I reach for it first. I take a bite into the pillowy treat and am instantly in love. The mochi is soft and chewy with a thin but elastic texture that makes it easy to bite off. It encompasses a soft subtle vanilla mousse filling, complemented by a more tart passion fruit puree. The ripe mango on top is the perfect finish. 

My black skirt is covered in the powdery dusting that are brushed on top of the treats to keep them from sticking but I am too occupied to care. The rest of the mochis are equally decedent though nothing can top the first bite I had.

‚ÄúHow was it?‚Äù Pavlo asks. I rave about them as I‚Äôm sure every customer does. ‚ÄúThe menu is interesting though- how did you come up with it?‚Äù 

Pavlo shrugs. I was a chef before this, he says. You learn things when you‚Äôre in a kitchen; you exchange knowledge and try new things whether it be Asian or European. (Continued in comments)

posts.caption:
One of the biggest reasons we traveled to Peru was to witness the stunning sight of hundreds of brightly colored macaws at the Tambopata clay banks. ü¶ú

Have you ever seen that many macaws in one place?

These vibrant birds flock to the clay bank between May and October, but our guide said September is the best time to catch them ‚Äì and wow, it was such a surreal experience!

Why do they gather here each morning? Scientists believe they eat the clay to detoxify from their fruit-heavy diets and get more minerals and salts ‚Äì a fascinating natural behavior we were lucky to witness! Tambopata National Reserve, a UNESCO World Heritage site, makes it easy for visitors to get up close to this colorful spectacle. Be sure to check out Smithsonian Magazine to dive deeper into the science and beauty of these incredible birds!

#peru #peruüáµüá™ #amazon #peruvian #amazonrainforest #macaw Peruvian Amazon, tambopata reserve, macaws in Amazon, Amazon rainforest must see

posts.caption:
15 favorite East Coast campgrounds...

1. Frisco Woods Campground, NC ‚Äì Tent, RV, and glamping right on the Pamlico Sound. Perfect for paddling, kiteboarding, and insane sunsets. 

2. Red Creek Campground, WV ‚Äì Tent only, unreal Dolly Sods views, rugged hiking, and that ‚Äúare we even on the East Coast?‚Äù vibe.

3. Jekyll Island Campground, GA ‚Äì Tent, RV, and cabins under Spanish moss. Walk or bike to beaches, driftwood forests, and sea turtles. 

4. Edisto Beach State Park, SC ‚Äì Tent and RV right by the ocean. Sleep under palm trees, explore salt marshes, and wake up to sea breezes.

5. Wilmington Notch Campground, NY ‚Äì Tent and RV (no hookups) in the Adirondacks, minutes from epic hikes, waterfalls, and Lake Placid.

6. Assateague Island National Seashore, MD/VA ‚Äì Tent and RV (no hookups) on the beach, with wild ponies as your neighbors and unreal sunrises. 

7. Big Meadows Campground, VA ‚Äì Tent and RV (no hookups) in Shenandoah with mountain views, deer wandering through camp, and easy Skyline Drive hikes. 

8. Watkins Glen State Park, NY ‚Äì Tent, RV, and cabins near one of the most breathtaking waterfall-filled gorges on the East Coast.

9. Kerr Lake State Recreation Area, NC ‚Äì Tent and RV camping right on the water. Lazy lake days, fishing, and campfire hangs.

10. First Landing State Park, VA ‚Äì Tent and RV sites, beachfront or mossy oaks. Great for beach days, kayaking, and dolphin spotting. 

11. Timberline Glamping at Williamsburg, VA ‚Äì Luxury glamping with safari tents, AC, real beds, and twinkle lights. Camping without the ‚Äúroughing it.‚Äù

12. Blackwoods Campground, ME ‚Äì Tent and RV (no hookups) in Acadia‚Äôs forests, minutes from rugged coastline views and Cadillac Mountain sunrises. 

13. North of Highland Camping Area, MA ‚Äì Tent-only, and a short walk from one of Cape Cod‚Äôs best beaches. Quiet, nature-filled escape.

14. Hunting Island State Park, SC ‚Äì Tent and RV right on a wild, unspoiled beach. Climb the lighthouse and look for dolphins. 

15. Ocracoke Campground, NC ‚Äì Tent and RV (no hookups) camping in the Outer Banks, only accessible by ferry. Wild, remote, and perfect for unplugging.

ai.title: East Coast Camping Adventures
ai.summary: 15 diverse campgrounds across the East Coast offering everything from beach camping to mountain views, with options for tents, RVs, and glamping.

time.bestTime: Perfect for overnight camping trips and multi-day adventures

cost.notes: Costs vary by campground type - tent sites typically less expensive than RV sites or glamping options

posts.caption:
which month is your favorite? 

JANUARY- try Piestewa Peak for sunrise.

FEBRUARY- head down to Tucson to hike Seven Falls, a seasonal waterfall that flows after winter rains and snowmelt from Mt Lemmon.

MARCH- hike the Jojoba trail at Bartlett Lake and see the spectacular wildflowers.

APRIL- the perfect time to catch Sycamore Falls flowing, a seasonal waterfall near Williams.

MAY- hike the Parsons Trail to a beautiful swimming hole in Sycamore Canyon.

JUNE- head to Payson to cool off at beautiful
Waterwheel Falls.

JULY- the White Mountains are the perfect summer escape, try hiking the Thompson Trail.

AUGUST- perfect temps up north in Flagstaff for hiking the Kachina Trail.

SEPTEMBER- it‚Äôs shoulder season in Sedona, which means less crowds. it‚Äôs a great time to hike Cathedral Rock.

OCTOBER- head north to Flagstaff to catch fall colors along the Aspen Trail Loop at Snowbowl.

NOVEMBER- we have reached hiking season in the valley. Tom‚Äôs Thumb is a beautiful trail to hike for sunset.

DECEMBER- Peralta Trail in the Superstitions is one of the most beautiful hikes in Arizona with spectacular views of Weavers Needle.

hopefully this gives you some inspiration and encouragement to try at least one hike each month! happy trails!

posts.caption:
My favorite waterfalls in New York üçÅüí¶ (be sure to SAVE for future trip planning!)

New York is absolutely underrated when it comes to natural beauty! There is so much to explore there, but ESPECIALLY waterfalls! These are my favorites. üëáüèª

üìç Taughannock Falls Overlook and State Park
You can either visit the overlook (pictured) for free, or pay to park at the state park and hike to the base of this waterfall!

üìç Letchworth State Park
This park is STUNNING and we were honestly shocked it wasn‚Äôt a national park. Make sure to hit up all the viewpoints of the 3 falls in the park, but Middle Falls Lookout is my favorite!

üìç Montour Falls, NY
This village is called ‚Äúthe valley of tumbling waters‚Äù for a reason! There are waterfalls all over the place‚Äîeven on the sides of the roads! Make sure to grab a coffee or tea at North New York while visiting!

üìç Buttermilk Falls State Park
This state park is lovely and has a great gorge hike alongside Buttermilk Creek. You can also camp there (and swim if you visit in the summer!)

üìç Watkins Glen State Park
Have you ever seen 19 waterfalls in one state park? Well you can here! This state park is one of my favorites ever and is worth the stop. Just be sure you go early enough in fall that the Gorge Trail is still open!

Have you been to any of these spots before? üçÅüß°

posts.caption:
Save these 20+ places for a New York State road trip‚¨áÔ∏èüóΩ

A lot of people don‚Äôt realize it, but if you drive a few short hours north of NYC, you‚Äôll find some really quiet and beautiful outdoor spaces. I love NYS, because you can spend the morning in the heart of Manhattan, and the same evening be up in the Catskill or Adirondack Mountains with nobody around. I‚Äôve always looked at living here as the best of both worlds, between urban and nature. If you‚Äôre planning on visiting NYS, these are some of the places I‚Äôd recommend checking out:

Hudson Valley:
-Ferncliff Forest
-Poet‚Äôs Walk
-Mt. Beacon
-Walkway over the Hudson
-Millbrook Winery

Catskills:
-Kaaterskill Falls
-Overlook Mountain
-Hunter Mountain Fire Tower
-Giant Ledge
-Devil‚Äôs Path

Adirondacks: 
-Whiteface Mountain
-Indian Head
-Mount Marcy
-Saranac Lake
-Ampersand Mountain

Central NY/Finger Lakes:
-Taughannock Falls State Park
-Watkins Glen 
-Buttermilk Falls
-Lucifer Falls
-Cayuga Lake

Western NY:
-Niagra Falls
-Letchworth State Park 

And if you do visit, it‚Äôs so important to remember to Leave No Trace and recreate responsibly. Explore the beautiful outdoors of Upstate NY while preserving its natural beauty for future generations.

Remember to:

- Pack it in, pack it out: Take all trash and belongings with you when you leave.
- Stay on trails: Prevent erosion and protect sensitive habitats.
- Respect wildlife: Keep a safe distance and don't feed them.
- Be mindful of campfires: Follow local regulations and fully extinguish before leaving.
- Keep water sources clean: Avoid soap and chemical contamination.

Let's leave places the Adirondacks and Catskills just as stunning as we found them.

As always, feel free to comment or message me for Upstate NY travel itineraries, recommendations, or hiking info. Follow @lukekellytravels for more travel ideas.

posts.caption:
@paulamoratal whisks us away to Valencia‚Äôs best-kept secret, Ruta R√≠o Fraile! üá™üá∏ ‚ú® This hidden gem boasts dramatic rock formations sculpted by time, crystal-clear waters perfect for a dip, and a scenic hiking trail for all levels. Explore hidden waterfalls, natural pools, and diverse wildlife! üíß ü¶Ö 

Getting to Ruta del Rio Fraile:
üìç The closest town is Bicorp, Valencia.
üöó You‚Äôll need a car to reach the trailhead. From Valencia, take the A-7 and CV-590 towards Bicorp. Look for signs for the ‚ÄúEcomuseo de Bicorp.‚Äù
üí∂ Parking is available near the official starting point, with a daily fee.

Hiking Routes:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Lower Route (Barranco del Fraile): This is the shorter and easier route, perfect for families and beginners. It starts near the Pe√±a Cortada swimming area and follows the river downstream, offering stunning views and natural pools. (Approximately 1.5 km round trip)
2Ô∏è‚É£ Upper Route (Circular Ruta del Fraile): This longer route offers a more challenging hike with breathtaking views. It winds through the canyon, passing waterfalls and hidden coves. Be sure to wear proper footwear. (Approximately 4 km round trip)

Best Time to Visit:
üìÜ Spring (April-May) and Fall (September-October) offer pleasant temperatures for hiking.
üî• Avoid peak summer months (July-August) as it can get very hot and crowded.
üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüëß Weekdays are generally less crowded than weekends.

posts.caption:
Did you know about this New Jersey beach?üåä

I wanted to gate keep this so badly but everyone deserves to know about this beautiful beach! I love that it‚Äôs free to enter (as every beach should be imo) AND the walk to the beach is super short (no lugging a beach chair for miles thank god). The sunset views are a huge bonus since you don‚Äôt get that at many NJ beaches.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no secret that mushrooms have skyrocketed in popularity over the past decade ... encouraged us to take mushroom-centric dining to the next level,‚Äù said Ravi DeRossi, whose goal is to transform the way people look at plant-based cuisine. ‚ÄúOur intention with this and all of our concepts is to offer elevated plant-based cuisine in an inclusive environment that appeals to everyone, whether they are vegan or not.‚Äù ‚Å†

The new 50-seat restaurant has a moody aesthetic, featuring handmade Spalted Maple wood tables‚Äîwhich feature ruggedly beautiful natural variegation hues as a result of fungus decay‚Äîalong with whimsical mushroom art in gilded frames adorning the space throughout. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The menu features thoughtfully prepared mushroom dishes, including Lion‚Äôs Mane Dumplings with daikon sauce; Black Pearl Oyster Mole Enchiladas with epazote sour cream; and Beech with cauliflower cream, nori butter, herb breadcrumbs and parmesan, among others. ‚Å†

posts.caption:
üìçPochuck Boardwalk - Appalachian Trail (Vernon, NJ)

Here‚Äôs what we did‚¨áÔ∏è

üìåPark in the Stairway to Heaven Parking Lot off Route 94 (limited parking available - some free parking and some paid parking - across the street from Heaven Hill Farm in Vernon)

üìåAfter parking, we crossed the street and began our walk along the Pochuck Boardwalk.

üìåWe made our way along this trail for about 40 minutes, and came across the 110-foot long wooden Suspension Bridge (beautiful scenery and views).

üìåWe turned around at the suspension bridge and went back the way we came to get back to our car.

üìåYou can continue beyond the suspension bridge if you‚Äôd like.

üìåIf you do what we did, then I would budget around 1.5-2+ hours to hike and enjoy the views.

üìåThe trail features numerous boardwalks, bridges, streams, and flora.

üìåIt is very picturesque!

üìåIt is relatively flat and easy, with a few stairs at some points.

üìåThere are bathrooms and snacks at Heaven Hill Farm near the parking lot for the trail.

Remember to carry out what you carry in. I recommend bug spray in the summer!üçÉ

Happy exploring, and don‚Äôt forget to follow me for more fun things to do in and around NJ and the Northeast!üòÜü•æ

#nj #newjersey #northjersey #njhiking #hikingtrail #njthingstodo #explorenj #visitnj #njisntboring

posts.caption:
3 NJ SUMMER ROAD TRIPS üöòüìç

There are so many destinations to explore not far from #Montclair ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs a quick 20-minute drive or an hour-long journey. A little about the three above: 

‚Ä¢ New Hope / Lambertville = the border of NJ + PA, these quaint little towns are full of antique shopping + food spots. It‚Äôs an hour drive, so can be done in a day-trip, but there are overnight options if you want to say too. 

‚Ä¢ Storm King Art Center = one of the world‚Äôs largest sculpture parks in New Windsor, NY. It‚Äôs an hour away and there are over 100 sculptures to explore. 

‚Ä¢ Paterson Great Falls = a 77-foot-high waterfall in Paterson, only 20 minutes from Montclair. 

Pack a picnic, grab your camera, and head to TheMontclairGirl.com to see our complete list of road-trips to take this summer.

posts.caption:
3 Days Finger Lakes Itinerary Details‚§µÔ∏è‚Å†
‚Å†
One of my absolute favorite getaways from NYC as you can see 3 Best NY State Parks while enjoying some amazing food and wineries of this Finger Lakes Region.‚Å† üçá 
‚Å†
‚Å†ùêÉùêÄùêò 0 (ùêÉùê´ùê¢ùêØùê¢ùêßùê† ùêÉùêöùê≤)‚Å†
After work, leave NYC and drive upstate to Ithaca and stay for 2 nights.‚Å†
‚Å†üöó ~4h from NYC‚Å† ‚Å†
‚Å†
ùêÉùêÄùêò 1 (ùêÉùêöùê≤ ùê®ùêü ùêñùêöùê≠ùêûùê´ùêüùêöùê•ùê•ùê¨)‚Å† üí¶
‚Å†
‚ú¶ Watkins Glen State Park - Start hiking this state park before sunrise for best experience as its really very popular. Opt for the Gorge Trail and see many waterfalls including famous Rainbow Falls‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ Cascadilla Gorge - An easy 0.5-mile loop trail that is picturesque and beautiful with hardly any people around.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ Ithaca Downtown - Stroll the pretty downtown of Ithaca and enjoy a fabulous lunch at Moosewood.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ Ithaca Falls - End the Day of Waterfalls with the absolutely breathtaking Ithaca Falls which doesn‚Äôt require any hiking.‚Å†

posts.caption:
This NJ forest is inhabited by over 100 charming fairy houses üßöüèæüßö‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüå∏ 

üìçNJ‚Äôs Fairy Trail - Free @southmountainconservancy 

These whimsical fairies inhabited New Jersey 13 years ago and you can see them in the woods of the South Mountain Reservation. This  fairy forest created by a mom for her son with autism. Now over 100 delicate fairy houses dot the landscape and are maintained by a group of volunteers who were inspired by the vision of Therese Ojibway who wanted to find a safe imaginate space for children especially those with special needs. 

üå∏On May 4, the Fairy Trail Festival will take place and will include  Three Fairy Tale Story Times10:30 am, 11:30 am & 12:30 pm.

üßö‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èBring a blanket and enjoy Storytime in the Locust Grove picnic area.
There will also be face painting, a scavenger hunt, ice cream, crafts and even fairy wings for purchase at the event. (Proceeds go toward the SMC Fairy Trail Fund)

üçÄPark in the Commuter Lot behind the Millburn Train Station

posts.caption:
Humans being humans watching sunrise at Cadillac Mountain üåûü•πü´∂üèº

The Cadillac Mountain sunrise in Acadia National Park was such a special moment. Experiencing the earth wake up with a bunch of other crazy strangers who also woke up early just to bundle up in blankets and sit on some rocks in the freezing cold was definitely one of our favorite travel moments.

This is the first place in the United States to witness the sunrise, so we felt so connected to the people around us and to nature. We watched the sky transition from darkness to vibrant hues of orange and pink. This experience was truly unforgettable üèîÔ∏èü´∂üèºüåÖ

We booked a permit to drive our car up to the top a couple weeks in advance and it was only a few dollars. Definitely worth it!

Are you team sunrise or sunset?! 

#sunrise #acadia #sunrisehike

posts.caption:
‚úÖSAVE This Post and visit Stoudtburg Village soon 
üìç3 Market Plaza, Adamstown, PA 19501

This European Style village is one of the ‚ÄúBest Kept Secrets‚Äù in Lancaster County. 

üìåThe village has cute little shops ( antique shops, doll repair shop, jewelry shop,book shop, a cute little bakery, I met the sweetest owner of the bakery shop, she makes some really cute house decorative items ,I purchased few items for my mum. I even did some antique shopping too.

üìåOpen only on Friday, Saturday & Sunday.

üìåThey even have live musics/ events on weekends.

üìåOnce you are tired taking pictures and shopping visit the German style restaurant to have a hearty meal. 
The food is really good.

üìå This is not a regular shopping village, the stores are very unique, the villagers ( shop owners) are extremely welcoming and friendly,

üìåSo if you visit one thing I can assure you that you will love it.

üìåI didn‚Äôt really find any kid friendly stuff, but definitely a kind of place where adults can have a great time.

So when are you visiting?

posts.caption:
üçÅPeak foliage now in Watkins Glens‚Å†‚§µÔ∏è‚Å†
‚Å†
New York‚Äôs prettiest state park, Watkins Glen State Park, is nestled in the heart of the Finger Lakes Region with 19 waterfalls and gorges that are sure to amaze anyone.üçÅ‚Å†
‚Å†
This park has been on my bucket list for so long but I always skipped it during summer due to insane crowds! This Fall I finally visited at sunrise and fell in love with this enchanted land filled with waterfalls, moss covered walls and innumerable steps amidst all the peak fall foliage!‚Å†
‚Å†
‚Å†
If you are near this region, VISIT NOW as Fall is the most magical time to hike in this State Park üçÇ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚Å†
‚Å†ùêìùêëùêÄùêïùêÑùêã ùêìùêàùêèùêí‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ Watkins Glen State Park is open year round from dawn to dusk‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ There is a small admission fee to enter the park ($10), which helps with maintenance and conservation efforts.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶  Trail Information:‚Å†
 - ùêÜùê®ùê´ùê†ùêû ùêìùê´ùêöùê¢ùê•: This is the main attraction with 832 steps, a stunning trail that winds through the gorge. Expect to get wet, as you‚Äôll walk beside waterfalls. It‚Äôs open until mid-late October.‚Å†
 - ùêàùêßùêùùê¢ùêöùêß ùêìùê´ùêöùê¢ùê•: Offers a higher, drier path with equally breathtaking views.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ Fall is a popular time to visit, so go early in the day to avoid crowds, preferably at sunrise.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶  The most beautiful spots to visit are:‚Å†
 - Rainbow Falls‚Å†
 - Cavern Cascade‚Å†
 - Glen of Pools‚Å†
 - Suspension Bridge ‚Å†
 - Frowning Cliff ‚Å†
 - Lily Pond‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ Don‚Äôt forget your camera; the park offers fantastic photo opportunities with the colorful foliage and waterfalls.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ Stay on designated trails, wear appropriate footwear, and be cautious of slippery rocks.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ There are restroom facilities and a gift shop near the park‚Äôs entrance.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ú¶ If you have more time, explore the charming town of Watkins Glen, visit wineries, or head to Seneca Lake or Ithaca for more scenic views.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚Å†
Video clips are taken on 22nd Oct 2023.‚Å† ‚Å†
